title: <s>[INST] [LOGIC_BOARD_PART_NUMBERS]820-3209[/LOGIC_BOARD_PART_NUMBERS]: Board part number 820-3209 fits a MacBook Air computer from year Mid 2012 whose model number is <s>[INST] [MACBOOK_MODEL_NUMBERS]A1466[/MACBOOK_MODEL_NUMBERS]: A1466 is a model number for a 13" size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437. [/INST]</s> with a screen size of 13" and an EMC number of EMC 2559 [/INST]</s>  ppvcore_s0_axg
message:
Hi. I'm trying repair an 820-3290. All rails ok except for <s>[INST] [SIGNAL_NAMES]PPVCORE_S0_AXG[/SIGNAL_NAMES]: This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead. [/INST]</s> and sub rails.

History "it worked then one day would not turn on".
No corrosion no signs of liquid and nothing visibly bad.

Here is what I have done so far:


Short somewhere on <s>[INST] [SIGNAL_NAMES]PPVCORE_S0_AXG[/SIGNAL_NAMES]: This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead. [/INST]</s>
Removed [RESISTORS]R7550[/RESISTORS] (4 lead)
Removed [RESISTORS]R7554[/RESISTORS] (2 lead)

Of 4 pin [RESISTORS]R7550[/RESISTORS]:
Pin 1 to [SIGNAL_NAMES]PPVCORE_S0_AXG_R[/SIGNAL_NAMES] == no short
Pin 2 to <s>[INST] [SIGNAL_NAMES]PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG[/SIGNAL_NAMES]: PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG Is a single phase of CPU VCORE for the graphics processor integrated into the CPU before it is combined into one PPVCORE_S0_AXG rail [/INST]</s> == SHORT
Pin 3 to [SIGNAL_NAMES]CPUIMVP_ISNS1G_P[/SIGNAL_NAMES] == no short
Pin 4 to lead 1 on [RESISTORS]R7554[/RESISTORS] [SIGNAL_NAMES]CPUIMVP_ISNS1G_N[/SIGNAL_NAMES] == no short


Dead short to ground somewhere between [SIGNAL_NAMES]CPU_AXG_SENSE_P[/SIGNAL_NAMES] and <s>[INST] [SIGNAL_NAMES]PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG[/SIGNAL_NAMES]: PPVCORE_S0_AXG_REG Is a single phase of CPU VCORE for the graphics processor integrated into the CPU before it is combined into one PPVCORE_S0_AXG rail [/INST]</s>
I have done some more desoldering - resoldering to eliminate top side board caps.

Any known common cause for the sudden falure and short on this rail?

title: <s>[INST] [LOGIC_BOARD_PART_NUMBERS]820-3209[/LOGIC_BOARD_PART_NUMBERS]: Board part number 820-3209 fits a MacBook Air computer from year Mid 2012 whose model number is <s>[INST] [MACBOOK_MODEL_NUMBERS]A1466[/MACBOOK_MODEL_NUMBERS]: A1466 is a model number for a 13" size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437. [/INST]</s> with a screen size of 13" and an EMC number of EMC 2559 [/INST]</s>  ppvcore_s0_axg
message: What are you calling a short. This bus will have a low resistance <5 ohm. This bus will also not be powered when no LCD is connected or recognized.

title: <s>[INST] [LOGIC_BOARD_PART_NUMBERS]820-3209[/LOGIC_BOARD_PART_NUMBERS]: Board part number 820-3209 fits a MacBook Air computer from year Mid 2012 whose model number is <s>[INST] [MACBOOK_MODEL_NUMBERS]A1466[/MACBOOK_MODEL_NUMBERS]: A1466 is a model number for a 13" size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437. [/INST]</s> with a screen size of 13" and an EMC number of EMC 2559 [/INST]</s>  ppvcore_s0_axg
message:
..... Oh. :o How is screen detected?

With screen connected, <s>[INST] [SIGNAL_NAMES]PPVCORE_S0_AXG[/SIGNAL_NAMES]: This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead. [/INST]</s>  = milliVolts. All other rails there, no backlight, no image, no chime, fan spin constant speeds up to full.

title: <s>[INST] [LOGIC_BOARD_PART_NUMBERS]820-3209[/LOGIC_BOARD_PART_NUMBERS]: Board part number 820-3209 fits a MacBook Air computer from year Mid 2012 whose model number is <s>[INST] [MACBOOK_MODEL_NUMBERS]A1466[/MACBOOK_MODEL_NUMBERS]: A1466 is a model number for a 13" size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437. [/INST]</s> with a screen size of 13" and an EMC number of EMC 2559 [/INST]</s>  ppvcore_s0_axg
message: First it needs to chime. These boards I have seen issues with the PCH. Try and press on it and power on and see if it works. Can also give it some heat 150C.

title: <s>[INST] [LOGIC_BOARD_PART_NUMBERS]820-3209[/LOGIC_BOARD_PART_NUMBERS]: Board part number 820-3209 fits a MacBook Air computer from year Mid 2012 whose model number is <s>[INST] [MACBOOK_MODEL_NUMBERS]A1466[/MACBOOK_MODEL_NUMBERS]: A1466 is a model number for a 13" size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437. [/INST]</s> with a screen size of 13" and an EMC number of EMC 2559 [/INST]</s>  ppvcore_s0_axg
message:
Ok so at this point I know there is no chance of [I]me [/I]fixing this board so I'll dump it and pick it up when I know more.
What I would like to ask about is order / sequence. Aside from the schematics, can anyone recommend online resources that will help me better understand?....
I can use gooogle (or I would not already have a business in tech) but if there are any sites that stand out as particulary usefull any links would be very much appreciated.

title: <s>[INST] [LOGIC_BOARD_PART_NUMBERS]820-3209[/LOGIC_BOARD_PART_NUMBERS]: Board part number 820-3209 fits a MacBook Air computer from year Mid 2012 whose model number is <s>[INST] [MACBOOK_MODEL_NUMBERS]A1466[/MACBOOK_MODEL_NUMBERS]: A1466 is a model number for a 13" size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437. [/INST]</s> with a screen size of 13" and an EMC number of EMC 2559 [/INST]</s>  ppvcore_s0_axg
message: Your best resources are here, youtube and google, but above all practice. Giving up on something cause you think you cannot fix it will not advance your skills in fixing these.

<s>[INST] [LOGIC_BOARD_PART_NUMBERS]820-3209[/LOGIC_BOARD_PART_NUMBERS]: Board part number 820-3209 fits a MacBook Air computer from year Mid 2012 whose model number is <s>[INST] [MACBOOK_MODEL_NUMBERS]A1466[/MACBOOK_MODEL_NUMBERS]: A1466 is a model number for a 13" size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437. [/INST]</s> with a screen size of 13" and an EMC number of EMC 2559 [/INST]</s>  ppvcore_s0_axg
message: What I do is put things on the shelf to figure out later. It's ok to give up today and come back to it in 2 weeks, 2 months, or even a year once you're better. My best revelations came when I Was fully defeated, bored, had nothing better to do, and picked up something that had kicked my ass six months ago with fresh perspective and new knowledge. If you are buying these to refurbish them you are in a much better position than someone like me who has to learn within the 24-48 hours I have to fix it before the customer has a temper tantrum!

[/INST]</s> with a screen size of 13" and an EMC number of EMC 2559 [/INST]</s>  ppvcore_s0_axg
message:
Fortunately my obssesive tendencys mean I can't stop working or studying and if I don't learn something new or make some money or progress in some way that day, I don't go to bed until I have. So, no doubt I'll have another go but definately once I have gone over the blackbox style power system architectiure page on the schematic and look at the blocks in detail on the schematic.

You think it would serve to read up on sandy, ivy and haswell and the various series chipsets (QM77, etc) a bit too?.

Good encouragement guys thank you
